images.copyright: 'The Wall for Peace' and the Eiffel Tower in Paris for the International Day of Peace (© Prisma by Dukas Presseagentur GmbH/Alamy)
images.title: 'The Wall for Peace'
images.caption: 'The Wall for Peace'
images.desc: In today's image, we're featuring 'The Wall for Peace' in Paris for the International Day of Peace. Since 2000, this exhibit, created by artist Clara Halter and architect Jean-Michel Wilmotte, has been inspiring visitors to write their own messages of peace and place them in gaps intentionally created in the structure for that purpose. To mark International Day of Peace, hundreds of events around the world are being held today, including peace fairs, music concerts, meditations, and more. The UN declared it a 'day devoted to strengthening the ideals of peace, both within and among all nations and peoples.' One of the events today is at the UN Headquarters in New York, where the Secretary-General will ring the Peace Bell and participants will observe a minute of silence.

images.copyright: Gewurztraminer grapes on vine at autumn harvest in Okanagan Valley, B.C. (© Henry Georgi/Age Fotostock)
images.title: Rich in aroma
images.caption: Rich in aroma
images.desc: Rich in aroma, the Gewürztraminer is a type of wine grape commonly used in white wine. It's sweet flavour tends to pair well with spicy foods. The origins of its name lie in the German word 'Gewürz' for spice and Traminer for a village in Italy. If you have a taste palette for wine, you can identify the use of the Gewürztraminer grape by its low acidity, wholesome texture and fruity flavours like peach, apricot and mango. A major characteristic is its sweet scent similar to lychee, grapefruit and rose petals. While these pink-skinned grapes are predominantly grown in France, they can also be found here at home, notably in Okanagan Valley, B.C.

images.copyright: A common loon in Superior National Forest in Minnesota (© Jim Brandenburg/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Fall for birding
images.caption: Fall for birding
images.desc: This common loon is spreading its wings in the Superior National Forest in Minnesota, near the border and along the northern bank of Lake Superior. As temperatures cool, the protected area becomes a birder's paradise as migrating flocks stop over on their flights south. Superior's 3.9 million acres and 2,000 lakes offer the right combination of water, woods, and wetlands to support over 155 species of birds, the most avian diversity found in any of U.S. national forest.

images.copyright: The Villarrica volcano in Chile on September 2, 2018 (© Cristobal Saavedra Escobar/Reuters)
images.title: Celebrating Chile’s Independence Day
images.caption: Celebrating Chile’s Independence Day
images.desc: That’s the Villarrica volcano providing fireworks for our observance of Chile’s Independence Day celebrations—called Fiestas Patrias—taking place September 18 and 19. The second-most active volcano in South America, Villarrica is known to the indigenous Mapuche people as Rucapillán (Devil’s House). This photo was taken on September 2, 2018, alarming nearby residents, but it wasn’t nearly as destructive as other relatively recent eruptions, like one in 2015 that prompted authorities to evacuate thousands of people.

images.copyright: Stoke Pero Common, Exmoor National Park, England (© David Noton/Alamy)
images.title: The wild romance of Exmoor
images.caption: The wild romance of Exmoor
images.desc: Welcome to Exmoor National Park, a patchwork of landscapes covering 691 square kilometres of south-west England. Here, grassy open moorland and heather-covered hills nestle up against wooded valleys, streams, waterfalls, farmland and some of the highest sea cliffs in the country – scenery which inspired RD Blackmore’s 1869 historical romance novel Lorna Doone.

images.copyright: Aerial view of trees growing in a forest, Vancouver (© Michael Wu/EyeEm/Getty Images)
images.title: Vibrant colours of Fall
images.caption: Vibrant colours of Fall
images.desc: With the first official day of Fall just around the corner, the days have gotten shorter, leaves have begun to change colours and trees have begun to shed leaves. If you are surrounded by deciduous trees, you will witness leaves in shades of yellow, orange and red. The coloration of leaves is a result of a chemical process that slows down the tree’s food-making process. The carotenoids present in leaves create the yellow and orange pigment and anthocyanins produce hues of red and purple. To soak in the riot of colours, be sure to check the reports on fall foliage and don’t forget to rake the leaves from your yard.

images.copyright: Surfboards in a row (© plainpicture/Tony Arruza)
images.title: Surfing through history
images.caption: Surfing through history
images.desc: Is there anything more quintessentially Australian than the sand and surf? We didn’t think so either, so with the weather continuing to heat up, there’s no better time to spotlight the humble surfboard. Yet as much as we Australians adore catching waves, surfing’s roots originally lie in pre-modern Hawaii and Polynesia. It is here that the sport was practiced by both men and women within all social classes, including royalty and commoners.
